 PARAGUAY STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT SECONDARY EDUCATION IMPROVEMENT PROJECT 1. BACKGROUND, ISSUES AND STRATEGY 1.1 Paraguay has recently begun to emerge from a long period of relative political and cultural isolation. The transition to a democratic system has been stable following the 1989 coup that ended the 35-year dictatorship. Extreme poverty is low and income distribution is better than average for Latin America. Despite some fluctuations, macroeconomic management of the open economy has been generally sound. However, key challenges remain, both to consolidate economic results and to further alleviate poverty. The education sector is central to the twin goals of sustaining growth and improving living standards. A. Recent Economic and Political Developments 1.2 Economic Strategy. Paraguay's real GDP growth rate averaged 5.6 percent annually between 1960 and 1992, the highest average rate in Latin America for this period. This performance was primarily attributed to abundant land for agricultural expansion; development of considerable hydroelectric resources; a defacto open economy that allowed the sale of goods to visitors from its larger, highly protected neighbors; and a small public sector which generated few distortions. However, economic performance was uneven over this period, with a long period of economic growth and macroeconomic stability during the 1960s and 1970s succeeded by economic deterioration in the early and rnid-1980s. The Government that took office in early 1989 sought to rectify the economic imbalances. GDP growth recovered to about 4 percent in 1993 and 3.5 percent in 1994. 1.3 Parallel to the internal reform progress, in 1991 Paraguay agreed to join a regional trade group comprised of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, Mercado Comun del Cono Sur (Southern Cone Common Market), or MERCOSUR. In the context of MERCOSUR, Paraguay has to contend with countries that have much larger internal markets, better infrastructure, more skilled human resources and comparative advantages in many of Paraguay's exports. To compete, Paraguay will need to invest heavily in human resource development and basic infrastructure, as well as to enact key legal and institutional reforms to attract needed investment. Without these actions, lack of a well- trained labor force may constrain Paraguay's competitiveness. 1.4 Poverty Conditions. Paraguay appears to be among the countries in Latin America where income is more evenly distributed and extreme poverty less widespread. Nonetheless, social spending has historically been very low. As a result, access to and quality of basic social services are uneven. Coverage of water and sanitation services is deficient at an average of 46 percent for urban areas and 12 percent for rural areas, representing almost half of the averages for Latin America. Infant mortality and life
 -2- expectancy are generally better than in many other Latin American countries. However, maternal mortality remains high and, with the exception of Bolivia, Paraguay has the highest fertility rate in South America. Even in the face of a rapidly expanding population, Paraguay has achieved nearly universal primary education coverage. This feat is not matched at the secondary level, where enrollment rates remain among the lowest in the Region (para. 1. 10). Moreover, quality of social services is an issue at all levels. 1.5 Democratization. A new Constitution was adopted in June 1992 and the country returned to democratic rule by 1993. Article 85 of the Constitution mandates that a minimum of 20 percent of the Government budget be spent on education. The Constitution also calls for basic education to be obligatory and free, and children to be taught in their maternal language during the first years of instruction. The new Administration places a high priority on improving social conditions, and has set out an ambitious agenda of educational reforms. Pressure to change the educational system stems as much from the desire to modernize and move Paraguayan society forward as from the desire to break with the highly centralized education system of the past With the creation of departmental governments (gobernaciones) under the Constitution, a political process has been initiated to define the roles and responsibilities of various levels of government, ultimately to include changes in resource flows and the entrance of new, subnational actors into the education system. This process may ultimately lead to a more decentralized education system and greater local control of schools. The challenge to the Government is to design technically sound proposals and to negotiate with a newly- embodied Congress which has demonstrated a proactive stance in the education sector. B. Education Sector Overview 1.6 Structure of Education. Historically, the education system consisted of six years of primary education for children age 7 to 12, six years of secondary education for children age 13 to 18, and four to six years of higher education. Within secondary education, the first three-year basic cycle was followed by a diversified upper-cycle (Bachillerato). The diversified secondary education system, introduced in 1974, offers concentrations in general (or academic), commercial, and technical areas. In addition, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock administers about ten agricultural secondary schools mainly in rural areas which award agricultural Bachilleratos. 1.7 The education system is currently being restructured to encompass nine years of basic education, divided into three-year cycles (see Annex 1): first cycle: grades 1-3, second cycle: grades 4-6, and third cycle: grades 7-9. Under the new structure, children will start basic education at the age of six. The upper secondary level, which will be called "middle education" (educaci6n media) under the reform, will continue to offer the existing three tracks: general (academic-oriented), commercial (business and public administration), and technical (industrial and other vocational education).
 -3- 1.8 Secondary graduates can opt for short-term, non-titular vocational courses given through the National Service for Promotion and Professionalization (Servicio Nacional de Promocion y Profesionalizaci6n, SNPP), or for four to six years of higher education provided by the universities and other professional institutes. Until 1989, only two institutions had full university status: the public National University of Asuncion (Universidad Nacional de Asunci6n, UNA), and the Catholic University (Universidad CatOlica, UC), a private institution subsidized by the state. Five private universities have opened since 1990. In addition, the Institute for Higher Education (Instituto Superior de Educaci6n, ISE) functions as the principal post-secondary teacher training facility in the country. The duration of training for primary teaching is two years and three years for secondary. ISE also offers a variety of in-service training programs. 1.9 Enrollment. Considering the fast-growing school age population and the country's largely rural and dispersed population, the achievement in basic education is laudable. The illiteracy rate is low compared with other Latin American countries, on a par with Costa Rica and the other Southern Cone countries. This is largely a function of high primary school enrollment rates over the last two decades. Gross enrollment rates have been above 100 percent since the early 1970s, reflecting universal primary school access for the 7- and 8-year-old population (see Annex 2 for basic educational statistics). Primary net enrollment rates are also relatively high at 95 percent by 1993. 1.10 In contrast, secondary school enrollment is one of the lowest in the Region. In 1992, gross secondary school enrollment was estimated at 33 percent, with net enrollment equivalent to 28 percent. This enrollment rate is well below both the average for the Region (47 percent) and for countries of comparable income levels (55 percent), especially compared with the Asian middle-income countries. Similarly, higher education gross enrollment at 8 percent in 1991 is less than half of the average for middle income countries (19 percent) and one of the lowest in Latin America. 1.11 Although growth rates for secondary education enrollment over the last ten years have been higher than those for primary or tertiary, this is an improvement off a very low base. Total secondary enrollment grew from 47,500 in 1969 to 212,248 in 1993 (Table 1.1). Two-thirds of all secondary school students are concentrated in the lower secondary cycle. In addition, over 80 percent of rural secondary students are enrolled in the lower secondary cycle, with access to the upper tracks limited in the rural areas to 5,240 students nationwide as of 1993 (see Annex 2). There are no technical track upper- secondary schools in the rural areas, and only a few offer commercial track courses. 1.13 In terms of enrollment by gender, no significant discriminatory patterns are found in Paraguay. At the primary level, male enrollment exceeds female enrollment slightly in the first few grades. However, the gap narrows as the grades get higher, with the overall share of primary enrollment of boys 51 percent versus 49 percent for girls. Considering that the repetition rate is higher among males than females, a larger number of male pfimary enrollment may be attributed to a larger number of male repeaters. At the secondary level, enrollment is comprised of 51 percent girls. At the post-secondary level, female enrollment at universities is significant (for instance female enrollment at the UNA is about 48 percent), and even higher in the post-secondary teacher training institutes where women make up three-quarters of the student body. 1.14 Principal Actors in the System. The education system is highly centralized. The Ministry of Education (Minis:erio de Educaci6ny Culto, MEC) is responsible for the provision of public education at the primary and secondary levels. Virtually all administrative functions of the MEC are centralized in Asuncion. However, seven regional education centers, designed in the 1 970s as model schools to provide the full range of educational opportunities including teacher training, provide contact points at the sub-national level. To date, municipal and the recently-created regional governments have not been active in the education sector. As for universities, under the Constitution, they are autonomous and have the authority to establish their own forms of administration. 1.15 Private Sector. The private sector plays an important role in the education sector, accounting for 13 percent of primary enrollment and 21 percent of secondary enrollment. These shares have been relatively stable over the past ten years. In addition, there are parochial schools officially classified as public schools, with school administration managed by religious organizations and teachers' salaries financed by the MEC. Of a total of 966 secondary schools in Paraguay in 1993, 683 were public, 242 private and 41 parochial. Private schools are usually more prestigious, and the quality and efficiency is higher than that of public schools. The quality of parochial schools is also generally considered to be higher than that of public schools. Although private and parochial schools are provided considerable freedom in terms of management and course content, they are required to follow the general precepts of the national curriculum, and are subject to evaluation by supervisors of the MEC. At the university level enrollment is largely public, although private sector participation has increased significantly. 1.16 Community Participation. Paraguay has a long tradition of active community participation in education. Parents' associations (cooperadoras escolares) support school and classroom construction and maintenance, finance the purchase and maintenance of
 -5- educational materials, and disseminate information on schools to the communities. In many instances, parents' associations pay incremental teachers' salaries, particularly for the creation of new courses at the lower secondary level, until such salaries can be absorbed within the public budget. The MEC is currently revising the decree to broaden and formalize the role and responsibilities of these associations, which henceforth will be legally installed as Comisiones Cooperadoras Escolares. 1.17 The MEC has supported the active participation of parents' associations largely as a mechanism for cofinancing educational investments at both the primary and secondary levels. A Social Action Department exists within the NEC to support and monitor the participation of the cooperadoras. In recent years, the MIEC has transferred funds directly to the cooperadoras to purchase equipment and materials and then carry out the construction of new classrooms either using donated labor from the community or by sub- contracting labor paid by the cooperadoras. The results have been significant, with 345 new classrooms built by this method in 1993 at the primary and secondary levels, for a total MEC disbursement of over US$1 million, and a reduction in unit costs. 1.18 Sector Financing Framework. The level of total government expenditures is low, and at 11.5 percent of GDP in 1993 was not only one of the lowest in the Region but one of the lowest in the world. This translates into limited public resources, in general, for the social sectors. As a result, Paraguay's public expenditures in education are among the lowest in Latin America (see Annex 3). While maintaining emphasis on universal primary school enrollment, this limited public spending on education has been possible through: (a) constraining access to the higher-cost secondary education; (b) sacrifices in quality at all levels; and (c) significant private spending on education. 1.19 In 1991', public spending on education was equivalent to only 1.9 percent of GDP, compared with a regional average for Latin America of 3.5 percent and well below countries at similar per capita income levels. In terms of the overall budget composition, education's share declined throughout most of the 1980s, falling from about 15 percent in 1983 to 10 percent in 1991. This trend was significantly reversed in 1992-93, when increases in teachers' salaries boosted education's share in the national budget to about 17 percent and its share of GDP to 2.9 percent by 1993. These recent wage increases represent the first real increase in teachers' salaries in the past ten years (see Annex 3). 1.20 Within the education sector, primary education has been the main recipient of government funds over the past decade. About half of public educational expenditures go to the primary level, slightly over 25 percent to secondary, and the remainder to higher education. This translates into a 1992 average unit cost per student of about US$134 for primary and US$245 for secondary. The lion's share of the education budget goes to pay wages. Teachers' salaries account for about 95 percent of the recurrent expenditure budget at the primary level and 99 percent at the secondary level, leaving few resources available for teaching materials, building maintenance and other inputs. Only in 1992 did real capital investments in education recover to 1982 levels. The MEC's administrative costs (including school supervision) accounts for about 18 percent of its budget. 1.21 Private spending is significant at all levels in both the public and private systems. Within the private system, a sample of private secondary schools in Asuncion revealed that 1994 annual tuition and fees (not including expenditures on books, uniforms, and other inputs) ranged from US$350 to US$1,000 per student depending on the quality and prestige of the school. Within public schools, private spending is substantial though not necessarily equitable. Parents pay through a combination of school fees, expenditures on textbooks, supplies and uniforms, and in-kind or cash contributions through the cooperadoras escolares. The payments are often greatest in areas where Government does not reach, such as more dispersed populations. Tuition and fees, at between US$34 and US$49 for public secondary schools depending on the level and track, are about ten to thirty times less than those of private secondary schools. While comprehensive and recent data are scant, a 1985 Bank sector review estimated that families were paying 23 percent of the cost of primary schooling, 36 percent of the cost of secondary schooling and only 18 percent of the cost of higher education. In 1992, in the schools with cooperadoras, 67 percent of the nonsalary costs were financed by these associations. While school tuition and fees are generally low, they did permit school directors to finance some basic inputs and services and the school level. Until 1993 public school fees were collected and managed autonomously at the school level. The Ministry of Finance has substituted a central collection system through the National Treasury, which appears to be less agile and may have a negative impact at the school level. C. Key Sector Issues 1.22 The main issues affecting the Paraguayan secondary education system, to be addressed by the proposed project, include: (a) limited and inequitable access to the secondary level; (b) generally low levels of learning achievement, and particularly in core skills such as Spanish, mathematics and sciences; (c) secondary school graduates often ill- prepared to satisfy the needs of either higher education or the labor market; and (d) weak institutional capacity to design and to execute the modernization and reform process. 1.23 Access to Secondary School. As described in the enrollment statistics (paras. 1.9-1.13), coverage at the secondary level is so low that it may constrain Paraguay's prospects for economic development. Demand is outstripping supply as reflected in the large wedge between primary and secondary enrollment rates and the large drop-off in enrollment levels between the last year of primary and the first year of secondary school. Parents queue for hours or even days to register their children at secondary schools, particularly in the peri-urban areas. School principals routinely base admission on the grade averages of candidates in order to ration the limited supply of places. Parental pressure often leads to one or two years being added on to rural primary schools to
 -7- accommodate aspirations for their children's continuing education. This constrained access tends to disfavor low-income students. 1.24 The access issue also affects quality. There is evidence of extreme overcrowding in many peri-urban classrooms, reducing teaching effectiveness and contributing to the wear and tear on school infrastructure. Even with active community participation, a backlog of infrastructure needs exists at the secondary level, including rehabilitation and construction of classrooms and complementary facilities to decongest existing spaces and to provide for new students. With 98 percent of schools operating on at least two shifts (often as a primary school in the morning and a secondary school in the afternoon), the MEC will find it difficult to increase access without the expansion of school facilities. 1.25 Learning Achievement Levels and Educational Quality. Learning achievements in the secondary education system are unsatisfactory. In 1991, only half of all secondary students who took final exams passed them. Greater problems are apparent in the lower cycle of secondary school, where only 57 percent passed the last year of that cycle, compared to 73 percent who passed the last year of upper-secondary school, reflecting a weeding-out phenomenon and the heritage of poor quality at the primary level. However, these statistics should be interpreted with caution as there are no standard academic achievement tests, and therefore results are highly dependent on the teachers' testing criteria and individual school performance cannot be compared. In addition to requiring a secondary school diploma, entrance exams are administered by each university faculty. Because of the low quality of public secondary schools, it is not unusual to have secondary school graduates take additional courses, often through the private sector, to qualify for university admission. The statistics of the past two decades reveal that only half of the applicants to UNA pass the entrance exams. 1.26 The determinants of student learning and the reasons for poor learning outcomes are complex. One of the issues is linguistic. Paraguay presents the unique challenge of a largely bilingual population, with 40 percent of the population speaking only Guarani. Under the national curriculum, Guarani is taught as a required language at the primary and lower-secondary levels. Based on the experience with a pilot program of bilingual education in the early 1 980s, the Government is embarking on a more ambitious bilingual program for the first three years of primary school. Nonetheless, this issue will continue to pose challenges of quality at the intake of secondary school, particularly in the rural areas. Attention needs to be placed on strengthening communication skills in Spanish at the secondary level to satisfy the demands of the modern labor market. 1.27 The usual deficiencies found in many countries also affect learning outcomes in Paraguay. Textbooks and materials available to secondary schools are largely outdated and are not consistent with the basic tenets of the Education Reform agenda, namely student-centered learning which promotes creativity, critical thinking, open dialogue, and problem-solving skills. Moreover, supply is scarce, and even where textbooks are available in schools, there is an administrative culture which tends to 'warehouse' textbooks as a school resource rather than promote their use as a student learning
 -8- instrument. School libraries and complementary educational materials are also scarce. In the case of laboratory facilities, those that exist remain significantly underused due to high maintenance and restocking costs, poor initial design and little training to optimize their use, as well as the pressure to use labs as regular classrooms in the face of overcrowding. 1.28 The quality of teaching practices is highly variable. Overall, teaching efforts are thwarted by overcrowded or inadequate infrastructure, lack of good textbooks and reference materials and a dearth of training. For years, low salaries demoralized teaching staff, although recent increases have begun to restore the viability of the profession. At the secondary level, inadequate salaries had created so-called "taxi teachers" in urban areas, who move between schools to maximize the number of shifts they teach during the day. The growth of secondary schools and the limited expansion of teacher training at the secondary level have created a shortfall of certified secondary teachers. Approximately one out of four secondary teachers have only secondary education. On the other hand, 28 percent of secondary teachers have a university degrees but have not had any teacher training in the area in which they are teaching. Expanded enrollment in secondary teacher training should address, in part, the short-term needs for new secondary school teachers. There are currently about 1,000 students being prepared as secondary school teachers. 1.29 One final element in low achievement levels is the limited amount of time students actually spend learning. For instance, the "time on task" is well below standards. At the primary level, the official school timetable requires only 680 hours per year of instructional time, in contrast to the average of 839 for LAC countries which is already the lowest among all the world's regions. At the secondary level, consistent international comparisons are not available, but the same pattern appears to apply. 1.30 Internal Efficiency of Secondary Education. Internal efficiency of the system, although better than in many countries in the Region has potential for improvement. The poor quality of statistics and methodological weaknesses of repetition, drop-out, retention and promotion rates call for a very cautious interpretation of these indicators. The average primary school student stays for 6.3 years, but only passes 4.8 grades. At the primary level, official statistics show an average repetition rate of 8.3 percent and drop-out rate of 4.2 percent for 1993. However, it is likely that actual repetition rates are higher than those reported2. Using a simulation model to estimate student flows, Schiefelbein and Heikkinen3 found an average repetition rate at the primary level of 20 percent and a drop- out rate of 5 percent. Repetition rates tend to be lower for girls than boys, for urban versus rural schools and for private over public schools. Overall, the student/teacher ratio at the primary level is 24, with an average of 30 for urban schools and 21 in rural areas. 2 For instance, students who drop out before taking the final exam are likely to be reported as new students rather than repeaters the next year. Though official statistics are not processed, at the secondary level estimates indicate relatively significant repetition and drop-out and low promotion and retention rates. The national average retention rate for the full cycle of six years is approximately 50 percent, with a range of about 14 percent for rural areas versus 65 percent in the Asunci6n area. Unofficial statistics estimate an average repetition rate of 9 percent and drop-out rate of 15 percent over the six years of secondary school. Average years of education of the work force have risen over time, from four to about six in 1992 for the population over 25 years old. EXPECTED BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Expected Benefits 5.1 The main benefits to be realized during implementation of the proposed project are: (a) improvement in the quality of the learning process through provision of better learning tools, teaching practices, and physical facilities; (b) partial satisfaction of the social demands for access to lower secondary schools, particularly from low-income urban and rural areas; and (c) increased understanding of sector and student performance, and the resulting enhanced capacity of the MEC to monitor and design sector policies. In the longer-term, this should contribute to a more productive and trainable workforce, increase the internal efficiency of the system, create a more dynamic and better-managed school setting, and establish the analytical foundations of evolving sector policies and strategies. 5.2 Poverty Impacts. Access to and improved quality of secondary education offers to increase the earnings potential and "trainability" of secondary school students and thereby improve individuals' chances of rising out of poverty. Although not included in the Program of Targeted Interventions due to the general profile of the secondary school population, eligibility criteria for the infrastructure component target schools with a low- income student population (para. 2.29). B. Expected Risks and Safeguards 5.3 Risks of administrative difficulties which hamper efficient procurement and disbursement and slow project execution, a common problem in Paraguay, would be minimized through the application of a PCU Administrative Manual to clearly define
 -40- administrative and procurement procedures, upfront agreement on procurement procedures and documents prior to implementation, and an Administrative and Procurement Review to address issues arising during implementation. Risks of inconsistency between the primary and secondary levels would be addressed through the incorporation of the lower years of secondary education into the basic education cycle and the implementation of the revised curriculum in a phased-in manner. On the operational level, the proposed project would be coordinated closely with the IDB-financed investment at the primary level. The risk of overload of the implementation capacity of the MEC would be mitigated through the preparation of an Operational Manual specifying implementation responsibilities and timelines, technical assistance and training to increase MEC capacity and the incorporation of flexibility into project execution through the preparation of Annual Implementation Plans. In addition, key activities will be sub- contracted outside of the MEC or phased in as pilot activities. The risks related to counterpartfinancing have been addressed through agreement on counterpart amounts and disbursement mechanisms, as well as incentives for community participation in education investments. The Bank's Asuncion Office in Asuncion, along with the annual Country Implementation Reviews, will monitor this issue. 5.4 Environmental Risks. The project is expected to have no significant enviromnental impacts. An environmental rating of "C" is assigned. 6. AGREEMENTS REACHED AND RECOMMENDATION A. The Ministry of Education in the process of establishing a National System for Evaluation of the Educational Process (SNEPE - Sistema Nacional de Evaluaci6n del Proceso Educativo) that would support educational policy decisions. The assessment of student learning is one of the main components of this national system. The IDB would finance the evaluation program for primary education and the proposed project would finance student assessments for secondary education. 2. The following section briefly describes the objectives of the secondary education student assessment program and highlights key elements of the program's: (i) institutional framework for implementing the system, (ii) technical design of the assessment instruments, (iii) test administration and analysis scheme, and (iv) promotion and dissemination strategies. Student Assessment Objectives 3. The main objective of the secondary education student assessment program is to inform educational policy decision-makers by providing periodic, valid, reliable, and timely information on student coenitive achievement and identifying factors that can help explain the differences in achievement. Institutional Issues 4. Institutional arrangements. A special unit in the Directorate of Vocational and Educational Orientation (DOEV - Direccion de Orientaci6n Vocacional) would carry out activities related to the general management and promotion of the system, test development and administration, and the dissemination and use of results. The unit would be composed of a director, a technical-pedagogical team, and an administrative team. All aspects related to data processing and analysis would be sub-contracted. 5. Strengthening local capacity. The DOEV's capacity to carry out its new functions is weak and therefore, strong capacity building efforts are required. During the project preparation phase, such efforts were initiated. For example, a workshop on selecting objectives and item construction was provided for the DOEV's staff and evaluators from other MEC Departments. The proposed project would continue such efforts by: (i) providing workshops on statistics, test construction and analysis, promotion and dissemination strategies, computer skills, and administration; (ii) financing study tours to foreign institutions with experience in assessment, and (iii) providing means for the DOEV staff to communicate with peers through journals, library development, and travel to professional meetings.
 - 61 - Annex 4 Test Technical Design 6. Cycles and grades. Assessments would be developed for students at the final grade of the educational cycles covered by the project, which would be the equivalent of ninth and twelfth grade. In 1997 and 1998, the present third and last year of secondary school would be tested (i.e., 3 and 6 curso). In 1999, after the extension of prinary education to a nine-year basic education cycle, the last year of this new cycle ( 9 grado) and the last year of secondary education (12 grado) would be assessed. 7. Subjects. The system would measure learning in the following subjects: Spanish, Mathematics, Natural Sciences, Social Studies and Guarani. Spanish and Mathematics would be the core subjects included in every national administration. Natural Sciences would be assessed in administrations for ninth grade and Social Studies in those for twelfth grade. Guarani would be assessed only after the curriculum changes of the Educational Reform are carried out; that is, only after Guarani is incorporated into the ninth and twelfth grade curriculum. 8. Reference. The assessments would be criterion-referenced, measuring knowledge and other key curriculum objectives of each cycle. 9. Number and ype of items. The tests that would be nationally administered in ninth grade would have 45 items per subject and those for twelfth graders would include 50 items per subject. These items would be multiple-choice. The tests for language at both levels would include an essay question. 10. Versions and Equating. For each subject, two parallel versions would be administered during the national administrations. In order to ensure that assessment results can be compared, the parallel versions would be equated. 11. Standardization. The content, administration, and scoring of the tests would be standardized. 12. Supplementary information. Along with each test administration, surveys for directors, teachers and parents wouldsbe carried out. These surveys would provide information on school-related variables (e.g., textbook availability, teacher characteristics, etc.) that enable the assessment data to be used for policy analysis. Test Administration and Analysis 13. Census and sample administration. The system would by sample-based, with the exception of census-based administration for ninth grade in 1999 and for twelfth grade in 2002. These census-based administrations would be carried out in order to monitor a complete cohort and evaluate the efforts of the educational reform.
 - 62 - - Annex 4 14. Years of pilot and national administration. Both pilot and national administrations would be carried out in October. Since the surveys would not vary from year to year, they would only be piloted at two points in the life of the project: a first piloting in 1996 and a second one in 2001 for updating purposes. The test administration plan for the period 1996-2002 is presented in Table I of this Annex. 15. Reliability and validity analysis. Reliability and validity analysis would be carried out for all tests. 16. Analysis and further research. Thorough psychometric analysis of tests and statistical analysis of results would be carried out. In order to attempt to explain the differences in achievement, the analysis of the results would include analyses of the relationships between the assessment data and the information collected in the surveys. The level of analysis would correspond to the type of adrninistration (census or sample- based). Optical scanning equipment would be used to speed data processing and thus, help ensure timely information. Furthermore, an up-to-date database would also be made available to educational researchers interested in carrying out further analyses of the results. Promotion and Dissemination 17. Promoting system andfostering evaluation culture. An information, education and communication (IEC) campaign would be carried out to inform supervisors, technical teams, directors, teachers and the public in general on the meaning and importance of national student assessment. It is expected that the EEC efforts would help gain support for the system and foster a culture of evaluation. 18. Targeted dissemination audience. The results will be disseminated to central, regional and local authorities, teachers, supervisors and the public in general. 19. Methods and timing of dissemination. Different reports and methods of dissemination will be used for the different audiences and directors, teachers and supervisors will be trained in the interpretation and use of assessment results. The formal dissemination of results will be carried approximately four to five months after the national admiinistrations (approximately in March of each year). 20. Monitoring the impact of the system. These dissemination measures are intended to influence actions at several levels of the educational system. The general performance information will provide an important quality check on the overall system and provide a benchmark against which educational managers and the cormmunity in general can judge progress. In terms of specific areas of weakness revealed in the test results, the content and orientation of the pre-service and in-service teacher training system should reflect efforts to address these deficiencies. Once the census-based results are available for each school, efforts to improve quality in the neediest schools can be more accurately targeted. Proposals for school-based innovations at the local level should reflect each school's particular performance challenges.

The Technical Quality functional area would be responsible for overall quality and impact of project activities, including: (a) coordination with MEC departments; (b) contracting of short-term technical assistance to address specific technical aspects of project implementation; (c) monitoring and updating of technical performance indicators; (d) coordination with agencies outside of the NEC, such as universities and private agencies, (e) compliance with reporting requirements of the project, including technical aspects for the annual progress reports, (f) support for the MEC in the preparation of Annual Implementation Plans; and (g) support for international and national experts in strengthening MEC capacity. 6. The Information Systems Unit would be responsible for: (a) design, installation and operation of an MIS system to monitor project implementation and administration; (b) provision of reliable and timely information to PCU management; (c) monitoring of performance indicators as established in the Annual Implementation Plans; and (d) provision of technological support to the financial administration of the project. Resource Requirements 7. The PCU would comprise about seven full-time professional staff and five support staff. In addition, short-term technical assistance would be contracted to: (a) carry out support to the PCU (computer services, information campaigns, etc.); (b) execute important monitoring functions, such as the independent audits and technical support to the Annual Strategic Planning Workshops and Mid-Term Review; and (c) balance peaks in
 - 91 - Annex I I work load, such as critical procurement periods or additional accountants to prepare for annual auditing. In Year I of project implementation, this short-term technical assistance would include the design and installation of a project management system to link monitoring of financial flows with the planning and execution of project activities and the overall performance targets. 8. The project would finance the equipment, consultants (short-term and fixed-term PCU staff) and operating costs of the PCU. The total base cost of this support amounts to US$2.3 million, or six percent of total project costs - well within efficiency parameters for project administration. Estimated PCU costs are distributed as follows: PCU higher- level personnel (40 percent), short-term consultants and audits (30 percent), operating costs (21 percent), support staff (5 percent), equipment and furniture (2 percent), and publications (2 percent).

doc.abstracts: The Secondary Education Improvement Project will support the Government's initiatives to improve the quality, efficiency and coverage of secondary education, and to increase the Ministry of Education's (MEC's) institutional capacity for information-based decision-making. The project consists of the following five components: 1) institutional strengthening; 2) provision of textbooks, educational materials and curricular support; 3) training for teachers and school managers; 4) infrastructure upgrading and expansion; and 5) pilot proposal for school-based innovation projects.
